# Sword

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to: navigation, search

For other uses, see [Sword (disambiguation)](/wiki/Sword_\(disambiguation\)
"Sword \(disambiguation\)").

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/08/Espadon-
Morges.jpg/110px-Espadon-Morges.jpg)](/wiki/File:Espadon-Morges.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Espadon-Morges.jpg "Enlarge")

Swiss [longsword](/wiki/Longsword "Longsword"), 15th or 16th century

A **sword** is a [bladed weapon](/wiki/Bladed_weapon "Bladed weapon") intended
for slashing or thrusting that is longer than a [knife](/wiki/Knife "Knife")
or [dagger](/wiki/Dagger "Dagger"). The precise definition of the term varies
with the historical epoch or the geographical region under consideration. A
sword consists of a long blade attached to a [hilt](/wiki/Hilt "Hilt"). The
blade can be straight or curved. Thrusting swords have a pointed tip on the
blade, and tend to be straighter; slashing swords have sharpened cutting edge
on one or both sides of the blade, and are more likely to be curved. Many
swords are designed for both thrusting and slashing.

Historically, the sword developed in the [Bronze Age](/wiki/Bronze_Age "Bronze
Age"), evolving from the [dagger](/wiki/Dagger "Dagger"); the [earliest
specimens](/wiki/Bronze_Age_sword "Bronze Age sword") date to about 1600 BC.
The later [Iron Age sword](/wiki/Iron_Age_sword "Iron Age sword") remained
fairly short and without a crossguard. The [spatha](/wiki/Spatha "Spatha"), as
it developed in the [Late Roman army](/wiki/Late_Roman_army "Late Roman
army"), became the predecessor of the European sword of the Middle Ages, at
first adopted as the [Migration period sword](/wiki/Migration_period_sword
"Migration period sword"), and only in the [High Middle
Ages](/wiki/High_Middle_Ages "High Middle Ages"), developed into the classical
[arming sword](/wiki/Arming_sword "Arming sword") with crossguard. The word
_[sword](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/sword "wikt:sword")_ continues the
[Old English](/wiki/Old_English_language "Old English language"),
_[sweord](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/sweord "wikt:sweord")_.[1]

The use of a sword is known as [swordsmanship](/wiki/Swordsmanship
"Swordsmanship") or (in an early modern or modern context) as
[fencing](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/fencing "wikt:fencing"). In the
[Early Modern period](/wiki/Early_Modern_period "Early Modern period"),
western sword design diverged into roughly two forms, the thrusting swords and
the sabers.

The thrusting swords such as the [rapier](/wiki/Rapier "Rapier") and
eventually the [smallsword](/wiki/Smallsword "Smallsword") were designed to
impale their targets quickly and inflict deep stab wounds. Their long and
straight yet light and well balanced design made them highly maneuverable and
deadly in a duel but fairly ineffective when used in a slashing or chopping
motion. A well aimed lunge and thrust could end a fight in seconds with just
the sword's point, leading to the development of a fighting style which
closely resembles modern fencing.

The saber ([sabre](/wiki/Sabre "Sabre")) and similar blades such as the
cutlass were built more heavily and were more typically used in warfare. Built
for slashing and chopping at multiple enemies, often from horseback, the
saber's long curved blade and slightly forward weight balance gave it a deadly
character all its own on the battlefield. Most sabers also had sharp points
and double edged blades, making them capable of piercing soldier after soldier
in a cavalry charge. Sabers continued to see battlefield use until the early
20th century. The US Navy kept tens of thousands of sturdy cutlasses in their
armory well into [World War II](/wiki/World_War_II "World War II") and many
were issued to marines in the Pacific as jungle machetes.

Non-European weapons called "sword" include single-edged weapons such as the
Middle Eastern [scimitar](/wiki/Scimitar "Scimitar"), the Chinese
[dao](/wiki/Dao_\(sword\) "Dao \(sword\)") and the related Japanese
[katana](/wiki/Katana "Katana"). The Chinese jian is an example of a non-
European double-edged sword, like the European models derived from the double-
edged [Iron Age sword](/wiki/Iron_Age_sword "Iron Age sword").

## History[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Sword&action=edit&section=1 "Edit
section: History")]

### Ancient history[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Sword&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Ancient history")]

The first weapons that can be described as "swords" date to around 3300 BC.
They have been found in [Arslantepe](/wiki/Arslantepe "Arslantepe"), Turkey,
are made from [arsenical bronze](/wiki/Arsenical_bronze "Arsenical bronze"),
and are about 60 cm (24 in) long.[2][3] Some of them are inlaid with
[silver](/wiki/Silver "Silver").

#### Bronze Age[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Sword&action=edit&section=3 "Edit
section: Bronze Age")]

Main article: [Bronze Age sword](/wiki/Bronze_Age_sword "Bronze Age sword")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ca/Apa_Schwerter.jpg/220px-
Apa_Schwerter.jpg)](/wiki/File:Apa_Schwerter.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Apa_Schwerter.jpg "Enlarge")

Apa-type swords, 17th-century BC.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/95/Nebra_Schwerter.jpg/220px-
Nebra_Schwerter.jpg)](/wiki/File:Nebra_Schwerter.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Nebra_Schwerter.jpg "Enlarge")

The swords found together with the [Nebra skydisk](/wiki/Nebra_skydisk "Nebra
skydisk"), ca. 1600 BC.

The sword developed from the knife or dagger. A knife is unlike a
[dagger](/wiki/Dagger "Dagger") in that a knife has only one cutting surface,
while a dagger has two cutting surfaces. when the construction of longer
blades became possible, from the late 3rd millennium BC in the Middle East,
first in [arsenic copper](/wiki/Arsenical_copper "Arsenical copper"), then in
tin-bronze.

Blades longer than 60 cm (24 in) were rare and not practical until the late
Bronze Age because the [tensile strength](/wiki/Tensile_strength "Tensile
strength") of [bronze](/wiki/Bronze "Bronze") is relatively low, and
consequently longer blades would bend easily. The development of the sword out
of the dagger was gradual; the first weapons that can be classified as swords
without any ambiguity are those found in [Minoan Crete](/wiki/Minoan_Crete
"Minoan Crete"), dated to about 1700 BC, reaching a total length of more than
100 cm. These are the "type A" swords of the [Aegean Bronze
Age](/wiki/Aegean_Bronze_Age "Aegean Bronze Age").

One of the most important, and longest-lasting, types swords of the [European
Bronze Age](/wiki/European_Bronze_Age "European Bronze Age") was the _Naue II_
type (named for [Julius Naue](/wiki/Julius_Naue "Julius Naue") who first
described them), also known as _Griffzungenschwert_ (lit. "grip-tongue
sword"). This type first appears in c. the 13th century BC in [Northern
Italy](/wiki/Terramare_culture "Terramare culture") (or a general
[Urnfield](/wiki/Urnfield_culture "Urnfield culture") background), and
survives well into the Iron Age, with a life-span of about seven centuries.
During its lifetime, metallurgy changed from bronze [to
iron](/wiki/Iron_Age_sword "Iron Age sword"), but not its basic design.

Naue II swords were exported from Europe to the Aegean, and as far afield as
[Ugarit](/wiki/Ugarit "Ugarit"), beginning about 1200 BC, i.e. just a few
decades before the final collapse of the palace cultures in the [Bronze Age
collapse](/wiki/Bronze_Age_collapse "Bronze Age collapse").[4] Naue II swords
could be as long as 85 cm, but most specimens fall into the 60 to 70 cm range.
[Robert Drews](/wiki/Robert_Drews "Robert Drews") linked the Naue Type II
Swords, which spread from Southern Europe into the Mediterranean, with the
[Bronze Age collapse](/wiki/Bronze_Age_collapse "Bronze Age collapse").[5]
Naue II swords, along with Nordic full-hilted swords, were made with
functionality and aesthetics in mind.[6] The hilts of these swords were
beautifully crafted and often contained false rivets in order to make the
sword more visually appealing. Swords coming from northern Denmark and
northern Germany usually contained three or more fake rivets in the hilt.[7]

[Sword production in China](/wiki/Chinese_swords "Chinese swords") is attested
from the Bronze Age [Shang Dynasty](/wiki/Shang_Dynasty "Shang Dynasty").[8]
The technology for bronze swords reached its high point during the Warring
States period and Qin Dynasty. Amongst the Warring States period swords, some
unique technologies were used, such as casting high tin edges over softer,
lower tin cores, or the application of diamond shaped patterns on the blade
(see [sword of Goujian](/wiki/Sword_of_Goujian "Sword of Goujian")). Also
unique for Chinese bronzes is the consistent use of high tin bronze (17–21%
tin) which is very hard and breaks if stressed too far, whereas other cultures
preferred lower tin bronze (usually 10%), which bends if stressed too far.
Although iron swords were made alongside bronze, it was not until the early
[Han period](/wiki/Han_period "Han period") that iron completely replaced
bronze.[9]

In South Asia earliest available [Bronze age swords](/wiki/Bronze_age_sword
"Bronze age sword") of copper were discovered in the [Harappan](/wiki/Harappa
"Harappa") sites, in present-day Pakistan, and date back to 2300 BC[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]. Swords
have been recovered in archaeological findings throughout the
[Ganges](/wiki/Ganges "Ganges")-[Jamuna](/wiki/Jamuna_River_\(Bangladesh\)
"Jamuna River \(Bangladesh\)") [Doab](/wiki/Doab "Doab") region of
[India](/wiki/India "India"), consisting of [bronze](/wiki/Bronze "Bronze")
but more commonly [copper](/wiki/Copper "Copper").[10] Diverse specimens have
been discovered in [Fatehgarh](/wiki/Fatehgarh "Fatehgarh"), where there are
several varieties of hilt.[10] These swords have been variously dated to times
between 1700–1400 BC, but were probably used more notably in the opening
centuries of the 1st millennium BC.[10]

#### Iron Age[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Sword&action=edit&section=4 "Edit
section: Iron Age")]

Main article: [Iron Age sword](/wiki/Iron_Age_sword "Iron Age sword")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d4/Hallstatt_%27C%27_Swords_in_Wels_Museum%2C_Upper_Austria.jpg/170px-
Hallstatt_%27C%27_Swords_in_Wels_Museum%2C_Upper_Austria.jpg)](/wiki/File:Hallstatt_%27C%27_Swords_in_Wels_Museum,_Upper_Austria.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Hallstatt_%27C%27_Swords_in_Wels_Museum,_Upper_Austria.jpg
"Enlarge")

[Hallstatt](/wiki/Hallstatt_culture "Hallstatt culture") swords

[Iron](/wiki/Iron "Iron") became increasingly common from the 13th century
B.C. Before that the use of swords was less frequent. The iron was not
[quench-hardened](/wiki/Quenching "Quenching") although often containing
sufficient carbon, but work-hardened like bronze by hammering. This made them
comparable or only slightly better in terms of strength and hardness to bronze
swords. They could still bend during use rather than spring back into shape.
But the easier production, and the better availability of the raw material for
the first time permitted the equipment of entire armies with metal weapons,
though Bronze Age Egyptian armies were sometimes fully equipped with bronze
weapons.[11]

Ancient swords are often found at burial sites. The sword was often placed on
the right side of the corpse. However, there are exceptions to this. A lot of
times the sword was kept over the corpse. In many late [Iron
Age](/wiki/Iron_Age "Iron Age") graves, the sword and the
[scabbard](/wiki/Scabbard "Scabbard") were bent at 180 degrees. It was known
as killing the sword. Thus they might have considered swords as the most
potent and powerful object.[12]

#### Greco-Roman
antiquity[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Sword&action=edit&section=5 "Edit section:
Greco-Roman antiquity")]

Further information: [Migration period sword](/wiki/Migration_period_sword
"Migration period sword")

By the time of [Classical Antiquity](/wiki/Classical_Antiquity "Classical
Antiquity") and the [Parthian](/wiki/Parthian_Empire "Parthian Empire") and
[Sassanid Empires](/wiki/Sasanian_Empire "Sasanian Empire") in Iran, iron
swords were common. The Greek [xiphos](/wiki/Xiphos "Xiphos") and the Roman
[gladius](/wiki/Gladius "Gladius") are typical examples of the type, measuring
some 60 to 70 cm (24 to 28 in).[13][14] The late [Roman
Empire](/wiki/Roman_Empire "Roman Empire") introduced the longer
[spatha](/wiki/Spatha "Spatha")[15] (the term for its wielder,
[spatharius](/wiki/Spatharius "Spatharius"), became a court rank in
[Constantinople](/wiki/Constantinople "Constantinople")), and from this time,
the term _[longsword](/wiki/Longsword "Longsword")_ is applied to swords
comparatively long for their respective periods.[16]

Swords from the Parthian and Sassanian Empires were quite long, the blades on
some late Sassanian swords being just under a metre long.

Swords were also used to administer various [physical
punishments](/wiki/Physical_punishment "Physical punishment"), such as non-
surgical [amputation](/wiki/Amputation "Amputation") or [capital
punishment](/wiki/Capital_punishment "Capital punishment") by decapitation.
The use of a sword, an honourable weapon, was regarded in Europe since [Roman
times](/wiki/Roman_Republic "Roman Republic") as a privilege reserved for the
[nobility](/wiki/Nobility "Nobility") and the upper classes.[17]

The [Periplus of the Erythraean Sea](/wiki/Periplus_of_the_Erythraean_Sea
"Periplus of the Erythraean Sea") mentions swords of Indian iron and steel
being exported from India to [Greece](/wiki/Greece "Greece").[18] [Sri
Lankan](/wiki/Sri_Lanka "Sri Lanka") and [Indian](/wiki/India "India") Blades
made of [Damascus steel](/wiki/Damascus_steel "Damascus steel") also found
their way into [Persia](/wiki/Persia "Persia").[18]

#### Persian antiquity[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Sword&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: Persian antiquity")]

In the first millennium BC the [Persian armies](/wiki/Military_history_of_Iran
"Military history of Iran") used a sword that was originally of Scythian
design called the akinaka ([acinaces](/wiki/Acinaces "Acinaces")). However,
the great conquests of the Persians made the sword more famous as a Persian
weapon, to the extent that the true nature of the weapon has been lost
somewhat as the name Akinaka has been used to refer to whichever form of sword
the Persian army favoured at the time.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/ba/Darius-
Vase.jpg/170px-Darius-Vase.jpg)](/wiki/File:Darius-Vase.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Darius-Vase.jpg "Enlarge")

[Darius I](/wiki/Darius_I "Darius I") of Persia holding an acinaces in his lap

It is widely believed that the original akinaka was a 14 to 18 inch double-
edged sword. The design was not uniform and in fact identification is made
more on the nature of the [scabbard](/wiki/Scabbard "Scabbard") than the
weapon itself; the scabbard usually has a large, decorative mount allowing it
to be suspended from a belt on the wearer’s right side. Because of this, it is
assumed that the sword was intended to be drawn with the blade pointing
downwards ready for surprise stabbing attacks.

In the 12th century, the [Seljuq dynasty](/wiki/Seljuq_dynasty "Seljuq
dynasty") had introduced the curved [shamshir](/wiki/Shamshir "Shamshir") to
Persia, and this was in extensive use by the early 16th century.

#### Chinese antiquity[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Sword&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: Chinese antiquity")]

Chinese steel swords made their first appearance in the later part of the
[Western Zhou Dynasty](/wiki/Western_Zhou_Dynasty "Western Zhou Dynasty"), but
were not widely used until the 3rd century BC [Han Dynasty](/wiki/Han_Dynasty
"Han Dynasty").[9] The Chinese [Dao](/wiki/Dao_\(sword\) "Dao \(sword\)") (刀
[pinyin](/wiki/Pinyin "Pinyin") dāo) is single-edged, sometimes translated as
[sabre](/wiki/Sabre "Sabre") or [broadsword](/wiki/Broadsword "Broadsword"),
and the [Jian](/wiki/Jian "Jian") (劍or剑 [pinyin](/wiki/Pinyin "Pinyin") jiàn)
is double-edged. The [zhanmadao](/wiki/Zhanmadao "Zhanmadao") (literally
"horse chopping sword"), an extremely long, anti-cavalry sword from the [Song
dynasty](/wiki/Song_dynasty "Song dynasty") era.

### Middle Ages[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Sword&action=edit&section=8 "Edit
section: Middle Ages")]

#### Europe[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Sword&action=edit&section=9 "Edit
section: Europe")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/46/Morgan-bible-
fl-29.jpg/290px-Morgan-bible-fl-29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Morgan-bible-fl-29.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Morgan-bible-fl-29.jpg "Enlarge")

Battle scene from the [Morgan Bible of Louis
IX](/wiki/Morgan_Bible_of_Louis_IX "Morgan Bible of Louis IX") showing 13th-
century swords

Further information: [Carolingian sword](/wiki/Carolingian_sword "Carolingian
sword"), [Romanesque sword](/wiki/Romanesque_sword "Romanesque sword"), and
[Longsword](/wiki/Longsword "Longsword")

Further information: [Oakeshott typology](/wiki/Oakeshott_typology "Oakeshott
typology")

During the [Middle Ages](/wiki/Middle_Ages "Middle Ages") sword technology
improved, and the sword became a very advanced weapon. It was frequently used
by men in [battle](/wiki/Battle "Battle"), particularly during an attack. The
[spatha](/wiki/Spatha "Spatha") type remained popular throughout the
[Migration period](/wiki/Migration_period "Migration period") and well into
the Middle Ages. [Vendel Age](/wiki/Vendel_Age "Vendel Age") spathas were
decorated with Germanic artwork (not unlike the Germanic
[bracteates](/wiki/Bracteate "Bracteate") fashioned after Roman coins). The
[Viking Age](/wiki/Viking_Age "Viking Age") saw again a more standardized
production, but the basic design remained indebted to the spatha.[19]

Around the 10th century, the use of properly quenched
[hardened](/wiki/Hardened_steel "Hardened steel") and [tempered
steel](/wiki/Tempering_\(metallurgy\) "Tempering \(metallurgy\)") started to
become much more common than in previous periods. The [Frankish](/wiki/Franks
"Franks") '[Ulfberht](/wiki/Ulfberht_swords "Ulfberht swords")' blades (the
name of the maker inlaid in the blade) were of particularly consistent high
quality.[20] [Charles the Bald](/wiki/Charles_the_Bald "Charles the Bald")
tried to prohibit the export of these swords, as they were used by
[Vikings](/wiki/Vikings "Vikings") in raids against the [Franks](/wiki/Franks
"Franks").

[Wootz steel](/wiki/Wootz_steel "Wootz steel") which is also known as
[Damascus steel](/wiki/Damascus_steel "Damascus steel") was a unique and
highly prized steel developed on the Indian subcontinent as early as the 5th
century BC. Its properties were unique due to the special smelting and
reworking of the steel creating networks of iron carbides described as a
globular [cementite](/wiki/Cementite "Cementite") in a matrix of
[pearlite](/wiki/Pearlite "Pearlite"). The use of Damascus steel in swords
became extremely popular in the 16th and 17th centuries.[nb 1][21]

It was only from the 11th century that [Norman](/wiki/Normans "Normans")
swords began to develop the [crossguard](/wiki/Crossguard "Crossguard")
(quillons). During the [Crusades](/wiki/Crusades "Crusades") of the 12th to
13th century, this [cruciform](/wiki/Cruciform#Cruciform_sword "Cruciform")
type of [arming sword](/wiki/Arming_sword "Arming sword") remained essentially
stable, with variations mainly concerning the shape of the
[pommel](/wiki/Hilt#Pommel "Hilt"). These swords were designed as cutting
weapons, although effective points were becoming common to counter
improvements in armour, especially the 14th-century change from
[mail](/wiki/Mail_\(armour\) "Mail \(armour\)") to [plate
armour](/wiki/Plate_armour "Plate armour").[22]

It was during the 14th century, with the growing use of more advanced armour,
that the hand and a half sword, also known as a "[bastard
sword](/wiki/Classification_of_swords#Longsword_and_bastard_sword
"Classification of swords")", came into being. It had an extended grip that
meant it could be used with either one or two hands. Though these swords did
not provide a full two-hand grip they allowed their wielders to hold a
[shield](/wiki/Shield "Shield") or parrying dagger in their off hand, or to
use it as a two-handed sword for a more powerful blow.[23]

In the Middle Ages, the sword was often used as a symbol of the [word of
God](/wiki/Logos_\(Christianity\) "Logos \(Christianity\)"). The names given
to many swords in [mythology](/wiki/Mythology "Mythology"),
[literature](/wiki/Literature "Literature"), and [history](/wiki/History
"History") reflected the high prestige of the weapon and the wealth of the
owner.[24]

#### Greater Middle
East[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Sword&action=edit&section=10 "Edit section:
Greater Middle East")]

The earliest evidence of curved swords, or [scimitars](/wiki/Scimitar
"Scimitar") (and other regional variants as the [Arabian](/wiki/Arab_people
"Arab people") [saif](/wiki/Saif "Saif"), the [Persian](/wiki/Persia "Persia")
[shamshir](/wiki/Shamshir "Shamshir") and the [Turkic](/wiki/Turkic_peoples
"Turkic peoples") [kilij](/wiki/Kilij "Kilij")) is from the 9th century, when
it was used among soldiers in the [Khurasan](/wiki/Greater_Khorasan "Greater
Khorasan") region of [Persia](/wiki/Persia "Persia").[25]

  * [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/25/Pala_type_of_kilij.jpg/42px-Pala_type_of_kilij.jpg)](/wiki/File:Pala_type_of_kilij.jpg)

[Kilij](/wiki/Kilij "Kilij").

  * [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/90/Sabel%2C_Shamsir_%28Persien%29_-_Livrustkammaren_-_13938.tif/lossy-page1-80px-Sabel%2C_Shamsir_%28Persien%29_-_Livrustkammaren_-_13938.tif.jpg)](/wiki/File:Sabel,_Shamsir_\(Persien\)_-_Livrustkammaren_-_13938.tif)

[Shamshir](/wiki/Shamshir "Shamshir").

#### East Asia[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Sword&action=edit&section=11 "Edit
section: East Asia")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3a/Antique_Japanese_%28samurai%29_katana.jpg/260px-
Antique_Japanese_%28samurai%29_katana.jpg)](/wiki/File:Antique_Japanese_\(samurai\)_katana.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Antique_Japanese_\(samurai\)_katana.jpg "Enlarge")

A Japanese wakizashi of the 17th century, with its _koshirae_ and _shirasaya_.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/22/Sword_with_Scabbard_MET_21123_-_cropped.jpg/220px-
Sword_with_Scabbard_MET_21123_-_cropped.jpg)](/wiki/File:Sword_with_Scabbard_MET_21123_-_cropped.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Sword_with_Scabbard_MET_21123_-_cropped.jpg "Enlarge")

Chinese _dao_ and scabbard of the 17th–18th century

As steel technology improved, single-edged weapons became popular throughout
Asia. Derived from the [Chinese](/wiki/China "China") [Jian](/wiki/Jian
"Jian") or [dao](/wiki/Dao_\(broadsword\) "Dao \(broadsword\)"), the
[Korean](/wiki/Korea "Korea") [hwandudaedo](/wiki/Hwandudaedo "Hwandudaedo")
are known from the early medieval [Three
Kingdoms](/wiki/Three_Kingdoms_of_Korea "Three Kingdoms of Korea"). Production
of the [Japanese](/wiki/Japan "Japan") [tachi](/wiki/Tachi "Tachi"), a
precursor to the [katana](/wiki/Katana "Katana"), is recorded from ca. 900 AD
(see [Japanese sword](/wiki/Japanese_sword "Japanese sword")).[26]

Japan was famous for the swords it forged in the early 13th century for the
class of warrior-nobility known as the [Samurai](/wiki/Samurai "Samurai"). The
types of swords used by the Samurai included the [ōdachi](/wiki/%C5%8Cdachi
"Ōdachi") (extra long field sword), [tachi](/wiki/Tachi "Tachi") (long cavalry
sword), [katana](/wiki/Katana "Katana") (long sword), and
[wakizashi](/wiki/Wakizashi "Wakizashi") (shorter companion sword for katana).
Japanese swords that pre-date the rise of the samurai caste include the
[tsurugi](/wiki/Tsurugi_\(sword\) "Tsurugi \(sword\)") (straight double-edged
blade) and [chokutō](/wiki/Chokut%C5%8D "Chokutō") (straight one-edged
blade).[27] Japanese swordmaking reached the height of its development in the
15th and 16th centuries, when samurai increasingly found a need for a sword to
use in closer quarters, leading to the creation of the modern
[katana](/wiki/Katana "Katana").[28]

Western historians have said that Japanese katana were among the finest
cutting weapons in world military history.[29][30][31]

#### Indian
Subcontinent[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Sword&action=edit&section=12 "Edit
section: Indian Subcontinent")]

_[Khanda](/wiki/Khanda_\(sword\) "Khanda \(sword\)")_ is a double-edge
straight sword. It is often featured in religious iconography, theatre and art
depicting the ancient [history of India](/wiki/History_of_India "History of
India"). Some communities venerate the weapon as a symbol of
[Shiva](/wiki/Shiva "Shiva"). It is a common weapon in the martial arts in the
[Indian subcontinent](/wiki/Indian_subcontinent "Indian subcontinent").[32]
Khanda often appears in Hindu, Buddhist and Sikh scriptures and art.[33] In
[Sri Lanka](/wiki/Sri_Lanka "Sri Lanka"), a unique wind furnace was used to
produce the high quality steel. This gave the blade a very hard cutting edge
and beautiful patterns. For these reasons it became a very popular trading
material.[34]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/62/Rajput_Khanda.jpg/220px-
Rajput_Khanda.jpg)](/wiki/File:Rajput_Khanda.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Rajput_Khanda.jpg "Enlarge")

A [Khanda](/wiki/Khanda_\(sword\) "Khanda \(sword\)") sword from India.

The [Urumi](/wiki/Urumi "Urumi"):(Tamil: சுருள் பட்டாக்கத்தி surul pattai,
lit. curling blade; [Sinhalese](/wiki/Sinhalese_language "Sinhalese
language"): එතුණු කඩුව ethunu kaduwa; [Hindi](/wiki/Hindi "Hindi"): aara) is a
[longsword](/wiki/Longsword "Longsword") with a flexible whip-like blade from
India. Originating in the country's southern states, it is thought to have
existed as far back as the [Maurya dynasty](/wiki/Maurya_dynasty "Maurya
dynasty") (322–185 BC). The urumi is considered one of the most difficult
weapons to master due to the risk of injuring oneself. It is treated as a
steel whip,[35] and therefore requires prior knowledge of that weapon.

The [Firangi](/wiki/Firangi_\(sword\) "Firangi \(sword\)")
([/fəˈrɪŋɡiː/](/wiki/Help:IPA/English "Help:IPA/English"); derived from the
Arabic term for a Western European a "[Frank](/wiki/Franks "Franks")") was a
sword type which used blades manufactured in Western Europe and imported by
the [Portuguese](/wiki/Portuguese_India "Portuguese India"), or made locally
in imitation of European blades. Because of its length the firangi is usually
regarded as primarily a [cavalry](/wiki/Cavalry "Cavalry") weapon. The sword
has been especially associated with the [Marathas](/wiki/Maratha "Maratha"),
who were famed for their cavalry. However, the firangi was also widely used by
[Sikhs](/wiki/Sikh "Sikh") and [Rajputs](/wiki/Rajputs "Rajputs").[36]

The [Talwar](/wiki/Talwar "Talwar"):([Hindi](/wiki/Hindi "Hindi"):तलवार) is a
type of curved sword from India and other countries of the [Indian
subcontinent](/wiki/Indian_subcontinent "Indian subcontinent"), it was adopted
by communities such as Rajputs, Sikhs and Marathas, who favored the sword as
their main weapon. It became more widespread in the medieval era.[37][38]

#### Southeast Asia[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Sword&action=edit&section=13
"Edit section: Southeast Asia")]

In [Indonesia](/wiki/Indonesia "Indonesia"), the images of Indian style swords
can be found in Hindu gods statues from ancient Java circa 8th to 10th
century. However the native types of blade known as [kris](/wiki/Kris "Kris"),
[parang](/wiki/Parang_\(knife\) "Parang \(knife\)"), [klewang](/wiki/Klewang
"Klewang") and [golok](/wiki/Golok "Golok") were more popular as weapons.
These daggers are shorter than sword but longer than common dagger.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f8/Kampilan_moro_sword_with_sheath.jpg/200px-
Kampilan_moro_sword_with_sheath.jpg)](/wiki/File:Kampilan_moro_sword_with_sheath.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Kampilan_moro_sword_with_sheath.jpg "Enlarge")

[Kampilan](/wiki/Kampilan "Kampilan") from the Philippines.

In [The Philippines](/wiki/The_Philippines "The Philippines"), traditional
large swords known as the [Kampilan](/wiki/Kampilan "Kampilan") and the
[Panabas](/wiki/Panabas "Panabas") were used in combat by the natives. A
notable wielder of the _kampilan_ was [Lapu-Lapu](/wiki/Lapu-Lapu "Lapu-
Lapu"), the king of [Mactan](/wiki/Mactan "Mactan") and his warriors who
defeated the Spaniards and killed Portuguese explorer [Ferdinand
Magellan](/wiki/Ferdinand_Magellan "Ferdinand Magellan") at the [Battle of
Mactan](/wiki/Battle_of_Mactan "Battle of Mactan") on 27 April 1521.[39]
Traditional swords in the Philippines were immediately banned, but the
training in [swordsmanship](/wiki/Swordsmanship "Swordsmanship") was later
hidden from the occupying
[Spaniards](/wiki/Spanish_Colonial_Era_\(Philippines\) "Spanish Colonial Era
\(Philippines\)") by practices in [dances](/wiki/Philippine_dance "Philippine
dance"). But because of the banning, Filipinos were forced to use swords that
were disguised as farm tools. [Bolos](/wiki/Bolo_knife "Bolo knife") and
[baliswords](/wiki/Balisword "Balisword") were used during the
[revolutions](/wiki/Philippine_Revolution "Philippine Revolution") against the
colonialists not only because ammunition for guns was scarce, but also for
concealability while walking in crowded streets and homes. Bolos were also
used by young boys who joined their parents in the revolution and by young
girls and their mothers in defending the town while the men were on the
battlefields. During the [Philippine–American
War](/wiki/Philippine%E2%80%93American_War "Philippine–American War") in
events such as the [Balangiga Massacre](/wiki/Balangiga_Massacre "Balangiga
Massacre"), most of an American company was hacked to death or seriously
injured by [bolo](/wiki/Bolo_knife "Bolo knife")-wielding guerillas in
[Balangiga, Samar](/wiki/Balangiga,_Eastern_Samar "Balangiga, Eastern
Samar").[40] When the [Japanese](/wiki/Japanese_Imperial_Army "Japanese
Imperial Army") took control of the country, several American special
operations groups stationed in the Philippines were introduced to the
[Filipino Martial Arts](/wiki/Filipino_Martial_Arts "Filipino Martial Arts")
and swordsmanship, leading to this style reaching America despite the fact
that natives were reluctant to allow outsiders in on their fighting
secrets.[41]

### Late Middle Ages and
Renaissance[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Sword&action=edit&section=14 "Edit
section: Late Middle Ages and Renaissance")]

Main articles: [Longsword](/wiki/Longsword "Longsword") and
[Zweihänder](/wiki/Zweih%C3%A4nder "Zweihänder")

From around 1300 to 1500, in concert with improved [armour](/wiki/Armour
"Armour"), innovative sword designs evolved more and more rapidly. The main
transition was the lengthening of the grip, allowing [two-
handed](/wiki/Classification_of_swords#Handedness "Classification of swords")
use, and a longer blade. By 1400, this type of sword, at the time called
_[langes Schwert](/wiki/Longsword "Longsword")_ (longsword) or _spadone_ , was
common, and a number of 15th- and 16th-century _[Fechtbücher](/wiki/Fechtbuch
"Fechtbuch")_ offering instructions on their use survive. Another variant was
the specialized [armour](/wiki/Armour#Early "Armour")-piercing swords of the
[estoc](/wiki/Estoc "Estoc") type. The [longsword](/wiki/Longsword
"Longsword") became popular due to its extreme reach and its cutting and
thrusting abilities.[42]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/d/d3/Battle_of_Kappel_detail.jpg)](/wiki/File:Battle_of_Kappel_detail.jpg)

1548 depiction of a [Zweihänder](/wiki/Zweih%C3%A4nder "Zweihänder") used
against pikes in the [Battle of Kappel](/wiki/Battle_of_Kappel "Battle of
Kappel")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1a/KHM_Wien_A_141_-_Ceremonial_sword_of_the_Rector_of_the_Republic_of_Ragusa%2C_1466.jpg/140px-
KHM_Wien_A_141_-_Ceremonial_sword_of_the_Rector_of_the_Republic_of_Ragusa%2C_1466.jpg)](/wiki/File:KHM_Wien_A_141_-_Ceremonial_sword_of_the_Rector_of_the_Republic_of_Ragusa,_1466.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:KHM_Wien_A_141_-_Ceremonial_sword_of_the_Rector_of_the_Republic_of_Ragusa,_1466.jpg
"Enlarge")

Ceremonial sword of the Rector of the [Republic of
Dubrovnik](/wiki/Republic_of_Dubrovnik "Republic of Dubrovnik") (15th century)

The [estoc](/wiki/Estoc "Estoc") became popular because of its ability to
thrust into the gaps between plates of [armour](/wiki/Armour#History
"Armour").[43] The grip was sometimes wrapped in wire or coarse [animal
hide](/wiki/Hide_\(skin\) "Hide \(skin\)") to provide a better grip and to
make it harder to knock a sword out of the user's hand.[44]

A number of
[manuscripts](/wiki/Martial_arts_manual#Historical_European_martial_arts
"Martial arts manual") covering longsword combat and techniques dating from
the 13th–16th centuries exist in German,[45] Italian, and English,[46]
providing extensive information on longsword combatives as used throughout
this period. Many of these are now readily available online.[45][46]

In the 16th century, the large [zweihänder](/wiki/Zweih%C3%A4nder
"Zweihänder") was used by the elite German and Swiss mercenaries known as
[doppelsöldners](/wiki/Doppels%C3%B6ldner "Doppelsöldner").[47] Zweihänder,
literally translated, means two-hander. The zweihänder possesses a long blade,
as well as a huge guard for protection. It is estimated that some zweihänder
swords were over 6 feet (1.8 m) long, with the one ascribed to
[Frisian](/wiki/Frisia "Frisia") warrior [Pier Gerlofs
Donia](/wiki/Pier_Gerlofs_Donia "Pier Gerlofs Donia") being 7 feet (2.13 m)
long.[48] The gigantic blade length was perfectly designed for manipulating
and pushing away enemy [pole-arms](/wiki/Pole_weapon "Pole weapon"), which
were major weapons around this time, in both Germany and Eastern Europe.
Doppelsöldners also used [katzbalgers](/wiki/Katzbalger "Katzbalger"), which
means 'cat-gutter'. The katzbalger's S-shaped guard and 2-foot-long (0.61 m)
blade made it perfect for bringing in when the fighting became too close to
use a zweihänder.[49]

Civilian use of swords became increasingly common during the late Renaissance,
with [duels](/wiki/Duels "Duels") being a preferred way to honourably settle
disputes. The practice of civilian duelling, with specifically designed
civilian swords such as the Italian [Cinquedea](/wiki/Cinquedea "Cinquedea")
and Swiss [Baselard](/wiki/Baselard "Baselard"), became so popular that
according to one scholar: "In France during the reign of [Henry
IV](/wiki/Henry_IV_of_France "Henry IV of France") (1589–1610), more than
4,000 French aristocrats were killed in duels in an eighteen-year
period...During the reign of [Louis XIII](/wiki/Louis_XIII_of_France "Louis
XIII of France") (1610–1643)...in a twenty-year period 8,000
[pardons](/wiki/Pardons "Pardons") were issued for [murders](/wiki/Murders
"Murders") associated with duels."[50]

The [side-sword](/wiki/Side-sword "Side-sword") was a type of war sword used
by infantry during the [Renaissance](/wiki/Renaissance "Renaissance") of
[Europe](/wiki/Europe "Europe"). This sword was a direct descendant of the
[arming sword](/wiki/Arming_sword "Arming sword"). Quite popular between the
16th and 17th centuries, they were ideal for handling the mix of armoured and
unarmoured opponents of that time. A new technique of placing one's finger on
the [ricasso](/wiki/Ricasso "Ricasso") to improve the grip (a practice that
would continue in the [rapier](/wiki/Rapier "Rapier")) led to the production
of hilts with a guard for the finger. This sword design eventually led to the
development of the civilian [rapier](/wiki/Rapier "Rapier"), but it was not
replaced by it, and the side-sword continued to be used during the rapier's
lifetime. As it could be used for both cutting and thrusting, the term [cut
and thrust sword](/wiki/Spada_da_lato "Spada da lato") is sometimes used
interchangeably with side-sword.[51] Also of note is that as rapiers became
more popular, attempts were made to hybridize the blade, sacrificing the
effectiveness found in each unique weapon design. These are still considered
side-swords and are sometimes labeled _sword rapier_ or _cutting rapier_ by
modern collectors.

Also of note, side-swords used in conjunction with [bucklers](/wiki/Buckler
"Buckler") became so popular that it caused the term
[swashbuckler](/wiki/Swashbuckler "Swashbuckler") to be coined. This word
stems from the new fighting style of the side-sword and buckler which was
filled with much "swashing and making a noise on the buckler".[52]

Within the [Ottoman Empire](/wiki/Ottoman_Empire "Ottoman Empire"), the use of
a curved sabre called the [Yatagan](/wiki/Yatagan "Yatagan") started in the
mid-16th century. It would become the weapon of choice for many in
[Turkey](/wiki/Turkey "Turkey") and the [Balkans](/wiki/Balkans
"Balkans").[53]

The sword in this time period was the most personal weapon, the most
prestigious, and the most versatile for close combat, but it came to decline
in military use as technology, such as the [crossbow](/wiki/Crossbow
"Crossbow") and [firearms](/wiki/Firearms "Firearms") changed warfare.
However, it maintained a key role in civilian [self-defence](/wiki/Self-
defence "Self-defence").[54]

### Early Modern period[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Sword&action=edit&section=15
"Edit section: Early Modern period")]

#### Military sword[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Sword&action=edit&section=16
"Edit section: Military sword")]

Further information: [Basket-hilted sword](/wiki/Basket-hilted_sword "Basket-
hilted sword"), [Backsword](/wiki/Backsword "Backsword"), and
[Sabre](/wiki/Sabre "Sabre")

A single-edged type of [sidearm](/wiki/Side_arm "Side arm") used by the
[Hussites](/wiki/Hussites "Hussites") was popularized in 16th-century Germany
under its Czech name _[Dusack](/wiki/Dusack "Dusack")_ , also known as _Säbel
auf Teutsch gefasst_ ("sabre fitted in the German manner").[55] A closely
related weapon is the _schnepf_ or [Swiss sabre](/wiki/Swiss_sabre "Swiss
sabre") used in [Early Modern Switzerland](/wiki/Early_Modern_Switzerland
"Early Modern Switzerland").[56]

The [cut-and-thrust](/wiki/Cut-and-thrust "Cut-and-thrust") [mortuary
sword](/wiki/Mortuary_sword "Mortuary sword") was used after 1625 by
[cavalry](/wiki/Cavalry "Cavalry") during the [English Civil
War](/wiki/English_Civil_War "English Civil War"). This (usually) two-edged
sword sported a half-basket hilt with a straight blade some 90–105 cm long.
Later in the 17th century, the swords used by cavalry became predominantly
[single-edged](/wiki/Backsword "Backsword"). The so-called [walloon
sword](/wiki/Walloon_sword "Walloon sword") (_épée wallone_)[57] was common in
the [Thirty Years' War](/wiki/Thirty_Years%27_War "Thirty Years' War") and
[Baroque](/wiki/Baroque "Baroque") era.[58] Its hilt was ambidextrous with
shell-guards and [knuckle-bow](/wiki/Knuckle-bow "Knuckle-bow") that inspired
18th century continental [hunting hangers](/wiki/Hunting_hanger "Hunting
hanger").[59] Following their campaign in the Netherlands in 1672, the French
began producing this weapon as their first regulation sword.[60] Weapons of
this design were also issued to the [Swedish army](/wiki/Swedish_army "Swedish
army") from the time of [Gustavus Adolphus](/wiki/Gustavus_Adolphus "Gustavus
Adolphus") until as late as the 1850s.[61]

#### Duelling sword[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Sword&action=edit&section=17
"Edit section: Duelling sword")]

Further information: [Rapier](/wiki/Rapier "Rapier") and
[Smallsword](/wiki/Smallsword "Smallsword")

The [rapier](/wiki/Rapier "Rapier") is believed to have evolved either from
the Spanish _[espada ropera](/wiki/Espada_ropera "Espada ropera")_ or from the
swords of the [Italian nobility](/wiki/Nobility_of_Italy "Nobility of Italy")
somewhere in the later part of the 16th century.[62][63] The rapier differed
from most earlier swords in that it was not a military weapon but a primarily
civilian sword. Both the rapier and the Italian [schiavona](/wiki/Schiavona
"Schiavona") developed the crossguard into a [basket-shaped
guard](/wiki/Basket-hilted_sword "Basket-hilted sword") for hand
protection.[64] During the 17th and 18th centuries, the shorter
[smallsword](/wiki/Smallsword "Smallsword") became an essential fashion
accessory in European countries and the New World, though in some places such
as the [Scottish Highlands](/wiki/Scottish_Highlands "Scottish Highlands")
large swords as the basket-hilted broadsword were preferred, and most wealthy
men and military officers carried one slung from a belt. Both the smallsword
and the rapier remained popular [dueling swords](/wiki/European_dueling_sword
"European dueling sword") well into the 18th century.[65]

As the wearing of swords fell out of fashion,
[canes](/wiki/Walking_stick_\(device\) "Walking stick \(device\)") took their
place in a gentleman's wardrobe. This developed to the gentlemen in the
Victorian era to use the [umbrella](/wiki/Umbrella "Umbrella"). Some examples
of canes—those known as sword canes or [swordsticks](/wiki/Swordstick
"Swordstick")—incorporate a concealed blade. The [French](/wiki/France
"France") [martial art](/wiki/Martial_art "Martial art") _[la
canne](/wiki/La_canne "La canne")_ developed to fight with canes and
swordsticks and has now evolved into a sport. The English martial art
[singlestick](/wiki/Singlestick "Singlestick") is very similar. With the rise
of the [pistol duel](/wiki/Duelling_pistol "Duelling pistol"), the duelling
sword fell out of fashion long before the practice of duelling itself. By
about 1770, English duelists enthusiastically adopted the pistol, and sword
duels dwindled.[66] However, the custom of duelling with
[epées](/wiki/Ep%C3%A9e "Epée") persisted well into the 20th century in
France. Such modern duels were not fought to the death, the duellists' aim was
instead merely to draw blood from the opponent's sword arm.[67]

### Modern history[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Sword&action=edit&section=18
"Edit section: Modern history")]

#### Military sidearm[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Sword&action=edit&section=19
"Edit section: Military sidearm")]

Towards the end of its useful life, the sword served more as a weapon of
[self-defence](/wiki/Self-defence "Self-defence") than for use on the
battlefield, and the military importance of swords steadily decreased during
the [Modern Age](/wiki/Modern_Age "Modern Age"). Even as a personal sidearm,
the sword began to lose its preeminence in the early 19th century, reflecting
the development of reliable [handguns](/wiki/Handgun "Handgun").[54]

However, swords were still used in [combat](/wiki/Combat "Combat"), especially
in [Colonial Wars](/wiki/Colonial_War "Colonial War") between
[native](/wiki/Indigenous_peoples "Indigenous peoples") populations and
[Colonial Empires](/wiki/Colonial_Empire "Colonial Empire"). For example,
during the [Aceh War](/wiki/Aceh_War "Aceh War") the
[Acehnese](/wiki/Aceh_Sultanate "Aceh Sultanate") [Klewangs](/wiki/Klewang
"Klewang"), a sword similar to the [machete](/wiki/Machete "Machete"), proved
very effective in close quarters combat with Dutch troops, leading the [Royal
Netherlands East Indies Army](/wiki/Royal_Netherlands_East_Indies_Army "Royal
Netherlands East Indies Army") to adopt a heavy [cutlass](/wiki/Cutlass
"Cutlass"), also called [klewang](/wiki/Klewang "Klewang") (very similar in
appearance to the US Navy Model 1917 Cutlass) to counter it. Mobile troops
armed with [carbines](/wiki/Carbine "Carbine") and klewangs succeeded in
suppressing Aceh resistance where traditional infantry with
[rifle](/wiki/Rifle "Rifle") and [bayonet](/wiki/Bayonet "Bayonet") had
failed. From that time on until the 1950s the [Royal Dutch East Indies
Army](/wiki/Royal_Dutch_East_Indies_Army "Royal Dutch East Indies Army"),
Royal Dutch Army, Royal Dutch Navy and Dutch police used these cutlasses
called Klewang.[68][69]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d2/Jack_Churchill_leading_training_charge_with_sword.jpg/220px-
Jack_Churchill_leading_training_charge_with_sword.jpg)](/wiki/File:Jack_Churchill_leading_training_charge_with_sword.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Jack_Churchill_leading_training_charge_with_sword.jpg "Enlarge")

British Major [Jack Churchill](/wiki/Jack_Churchill "Jack Churchill") (far
right) leads Commandos during a training exercise, sword in hand, in [World
War II](/wiki/World_War_II "World War II").

Swords continued in general peacetime use by cavalry of most armies during the
years prior to World War I. For example, the British Army formally adopted a
completely new design of [cavalry
sword](/wiki/1908_and_1912_Pattern_British_Army_Cavalry_Swords "1908 and 1912
Pattern British Army Cavalry Swords") in 1908, almost the last change in
British Army weapons before the outbreak of the war.[70] At the outbreak of
World War I infantry officers in all combatant armies still carried swords as
part of their field equipment. On mobilization in August 1914 all serving
British Army officers were required to have their swords sharpened as the only
peacetime use of the weapon had been for saluting on parade.[71] The high
visibility and limited practical use of the sword however led to it being
abandoned within weeks, although most cavalry continued to carry sabres
throughout the War. It was not until the late 1920s and early 1930s that this
historic weapon was finally discarded for all but ceremonial purposes by most
remaining horse mounted regiments of Europe and the Americas.

In China troops used the long anti-cavalry [Miao dao](/wiki/Miao_dao "Miao
dao") well into the [Second Sino-Japanese War](/wiki/Second_Sino-Japanese_War
"Second Sino-Japanese War"). The last units of British heavy cavalry switched
to using [armoured vehicles](/wiki/Armoured_vehicle "Armoured vehicle") as
late as 1938. Swords and other dedicated melee weapons were used occasionally
by many countries during [World War II](/wiki/World_War_II "World War II"),
but typically as a secondary weapon as they were outclassed by coexisting
[firearms](/wiki/Firearm "Firearm").[72][73][74]

#### Ceremonial use[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Sword&action=edit&section=20
"Edit section: Ceremonial use")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/06/Szczerbiec.PNG/170px-
Szczerbiec.PNG)](/wiki/File:Szczerbiec.PNG)

[](/wiki/File:Szczerbiec.PNG "Enlarge")

Graphical documentation of the [Szczerbiec](/wiki/Szczerbiec "Szczerbiec"), a
sword that was traditionally used in the coronation ceremony of [Polish
kings](/wiki/Rulers_of_Poland "Rulers of Poland"), 12th-13th century.

Further information: [Sword of State](/wiki/Sword_of_State "Sword of State")

Swords are commonly worn as a [ceremonial item](/wiki/Ceremonial_weapon
"Ceremonial weapon") by officers in many military and naval services
throughout the world. Occasions to wear swords include any event in dress
uniforms where the rank-and-file carry arms: [parades](/wiki/Parade "Parade"),
reviews, [courts-martial](/wiki/Swords_in_courts-martial "Swords in courts-
martial"), [tattoos](/wiki/Military_tattoo "Military tattoo"), and changes of
command. They are also commonly worn for officers' weddings, and when wearing
dress uniforms to church—although they are rarely actually worn in the church
itself.

In the British forces they are also worn for any appearance at
[Court](/wiki/Court_\(royal\) "Court \(royal\)"). In the [United
States](/wiki/United_States "United States"), every Naval officer at or above
the rank of [Lieutenant Commander](/wiki/Lieutenant_Commander "Lieutenant
Commander") is required to own a sword, which can be prescribed for any formal
outdoor ceremonial occasion; they are normally worn for changes of command and
parades. For some Navy parades, [cutlasses](/wiki/Cutlasses "Cutlasses") are
issued to [Petty Officers](/wiki/Petty_Officers "Petty Officers") and [Chief
Petty Officers](/wiki/Chief_Petty_Officer "Chief Petty Officer").

In the [U.S. Marine Corps](/wiki/U.S._Marine_Corps "U.S. Marine Corps") every
officer must own a sword, which is prescribed for formal parades and other
ceremonies where dress uniforms are worn and the rank-and-file are under arms.
On these occasions depending on their billet, Marine Staff Non-Commissioned
Officers (E-6 and above) may also be required to carry swords, which have
hilts of a pattern similar to U.S. Naval officers' swords but are actually
[sabres](/wiki/Sabre "Sabre"). The USMC [Model 1859 NCO
Sword](/wiki/United_States_Marine_Corps_noncommissioned_officer%27s_sword
"United States Marine Corps noncommissioned officer's sword") is the longest
continuously-issued edged weapon in the U.S. inventory

The Marine officer swords are of the [Mameluke](/wiki/Mameluke_sword "Mameluke
sword") pattern which was adopted in 1825 in recognition of the Marines' key
role in the capture of the [Tripolitan](/wiki/Tripoli#The_Barbary_Wars
"Tripoli") city of [Derna](/wiki/Battle_of_Derna "Battle of Derna") during the
[First Barbary War](/wiki/First_Barbary_War "First Barbary War").[75] Taken
out of issue for approximately 20 years from 1855 until 1875, it was restored
to service in the year of the Corps' centennial and has remained in issue
since.

#### Sword replicas[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Sword&action=edit&section=21
"Edit section: Sword replicas")]

Main article: [Sword replica](/wiki/Sword_replica "Sword replica")

The production of [replicas](/wiki/Sword_replica "Sword replica") of
historical swords originates with 19th-century
[historicism](/wiki/Historicism_\(art\) "Historicism \(art\)").[76]
Contemporary replicas can range from cheap factory produced look-alikes to
exact recreations of individual artifacts, including an approximation of the
historical production methods.

Some kinds of swords are still commonly used today as weapons, often as a side
arm for military infantry. The Japanese katana, wakizashi and tanto are
carried by some infantry and officers in Japan and other parts of Asia and the
[kukri](/wiki/Kukri "Kukri") is the official melee weapon for
[Nepal](/wiki/Nepal "Nepal"). Other swords in use today are the
[sabre](/wiki/Sabre "Sabre"), the [scimitar](/wiki/Scimitar "Scimitar"), the
[shortsword](/wiki/Shortsword "Shortsword") and the [machete](/wiki/Machete
"Machete").[77]

  * In the case of a rat-tail [tang](/wiki/Tang_\(tools\) "Tang \(tools\)"), the maker welds a thin rod to the end of the blade at the crossguard; this rod goes through the grip.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]
  * In traditional construction, Swordsmiths [peened](/wiki/Peening "Peening") such tangs over the end of the pommel, or occasionally welded the hilt furniture to the tang and threaded the end for screwing on a pommel. This style is often referred to as a "narrow" or "hidden" tang. Modern, less traditional, replicas often feature a threaded pommel or a pommel nut which holds the hilt together and allows dismantling.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]
  * In a "full" tang (most commonly used in knives and [machetes](/wiki/Machete "Machete")), the tang has about the same width as the blade, and is generally the same shape as the grip.[78] In European or Asian swords sold today, many advertised "full" tangs may actually involve a forged rat-tail tang.

## Morphology[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Sword&action=edit&section=22 "Edit
section: Morphology")]

Further information: [Classification of swords](/wiki/Classification_of_swords
"Classification of swords")

The sword consists of the [blade](/wiki/Blade "Blade") and the
[hilt](/wiki/Hilt "Hilt"). The term _[scabbard](/wiki/Scabbard "Scabbard")_
applies to the cover for the sword blade when not in use.

### Blade[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Sword&action=edit&section=23 "Edit
section: Blade")]

Main articles: [Sword blade](/wiki/Sword_blade "Sword blade") and [Oakeshott
typology](/wiki/Oakeshott_typology "Oakeshott typology")

[![Sword parts-
en.svg](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/78/Sword_parts-
en.svg/512px-Sword_parts-en.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Sword_parts-en.svg)

There is considerable variation in the detailed design of sword blades. The
diagram opposite shows a typical Medieval European sword.

Early iron blades have rounded points due to the limited metallurgy of the
time. These were still effective for thrusting against lightly armoured
opponents. As armour advanced, blades were made narrower, stiffer and sharply
pointed to defeat the armour by thrusting.

Dedicated cutting blades are wide and thin, and often have grooves known as
[fullers](/wiki/Fuller_\(weapon\) "Fuller \(weapon\)") which lighten the blade
at the cost of some of the blade's stiffness. The edges of a cutting sword are
almost parallel. Blades oriented for the thrust have thicker blades, sometimes
with a distinct midrib for increased stiffness, with a strong taper and an
acute point. The geometry of a cutting sword blade allows for acute edge
angles. It should be noted, however, that an edge with an acuter angle is more
inclined to degrade quickly in combat situations than an edge with a more
obtuse angle. Also, an acute edge angle is not the primary factor of a blade's
sharpness.[79]

The part of the blade between the [center of
percussion](/wiki/Center_of_percussion "Center of percussion") (CoP) and the
point is called the _foible_ (weak) of the blade, and that between the [center
of balance](/wiki/Center_of_gravity "Center of gravity") (CoB) and the hilt is
the _forte_ (strong). The section in between the CoP and the CoB is the
_middle_.

The _[ricasso](/wiki/Ricasso "Ricasso")_ or _shoulder_ identifies a short
section of blade immediately below the guard that is left completely
unsharpened. Many swords have no ricasso. On some large weapons, such as the
[German](/wiki/Germany "Germany") _[Zweihänder](/wiki/Zweih%C3%A4nder
"Zweihänder")_ , a metal cover surrounded the ricasso, and a swordsman might
grip it in one hand to wield the weapon more easily in close-quarter
combat.[49] The ricasso normally bears the [maker's mark](/wiki/Trademark
"Trademark").

The [tang](/wiki/Tang_\(tools\) "Tang \(tools\)") is the extension of the
blade to which the hilt is fitted.

On Japanese blades, the maker's mark appears on the tang under the grip.[80]

### Hilt[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Sword&action=edit&section=24 "Edit section:
Hilt")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/95/Rapier_mg_3370-no_shadows.jpg/170px-
Rapier_mg_3370-no_shadows.jpg)](/wiki/File:Rapier_mg_3370-no_shadows.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Rapier_mg_3370-no_shadows.jpg "Enlarge")

Hilt of a [rapier](/wiki/Rapier "Rapier"). In this case, with a swept hilt

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b6/Sword_of_Umar_ibn_al-
Khittab-mohammad_adil_rais.JPG/150px-Sword_of_Umar_ibn_al-Khittab-
mohammad_adil_rais.JPG)](/wiki/File:Sword_of_Umar_ibn_al-Khittab-
mohammad_adil_rais.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:Sword_of_Umar_ibn_al-Khittab-mohammad_adil_rais.JPG "Enlarge")

Sword of [Caliph Umar](/wiki/Caliph_Umar "Caliph Umar"), with later hilt.

The [hilt](/wiki/Hilt "Hilt") is the collective term for the parts allowing
for the handling and control of the blade; these consist of the
[grip](/wiki/Hilt#Grip "Hilt"), the [pommel](/wiki/Hilt#Pommel "Hilt"), and a
simple or elaborate [guard](/wiki/Guard_\(weapon\) "Guard \(weapon\)"), which
in post-[Viking Age](/wiki/Viking_Age "Viking Age") swords could consist of
only a [crossguard](/wiki/Crossguard "Crossguard") (called a
[cruciform](/wiki/Cruciform "Cruciform") hilt or [quillons](/wiki/Quillons
"Quillons")). The pommel was originally designed as a stop to prevent the
sword slipping from the hand. From around the 11th century onward it became a
counterbalance to the blade, allowing a more fluid style of
fighting.[_[dubious](/wiki/Wikipedia:Accuracy_dispute#Disputed_statement
"Wikipedia:Accuracy dispute") – [discuss](/wiki/Talk:Sword#Dubious
"Talk:Sword")_][81] It can also be used as a blunt instrument at close range,
and its weight affects the centre of percussion. In later times a _[sword
knot](/wiki/Hilt#Sword_knot "Hilt")_ or _[tassel](/wiki/Hilt#Sword_knot
"Hilt")_ was sometimes added. By the 17th century, with the growing use of
firearms and the accompanying decline in the use of [armour](/wiki/Armour
"Armour"), many [rapiers](/wiki/Rapier "Rapier") and [dueling
swords](/wiki/European_dueling_sword "European dueling sword") had developed
elaborate basket hilts, which protect the palm of the wielder and rendered the
[gauntlet](/wiki/Gauntlet_\(glove\) "Gauntlet \(glove\)") obsolete.[82]

In late medieval and Renaissance era European swords, a flap of leather called
the _chappe_ or _rain guard_ was attached to a sword's
[crossguard](/wiki/Crossguard "Crossguard") at the base of the hilt to protect
the mouth of the scabbard and prevent water from entering.[83]

### Sword scabbards and
suspension[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Sword&action=edit&section=25 "Edit
section: Sword scabbards and suspension")]

Main article: [Scabbard](/wiki/Scabbard "Scabbard")

Common accessories to the sword include the [scabbard](/wiki/Scabbard
"Scabbard"), as well as the _sword belt_.

  * **Scabbard** : The scabbard, also known as the **sheath** , is a protective cover often provided for the sword blade. Over the millennia, scabbards have been made of many materials, including leather, wood, and metals such as brass or steel. The metal fitting where the blade enters the leather or metal scabbard is called the **throat** , which is often part of a larger scabbard **mount** , or **locket** , that bears a carrying ring or stud to facilitate wearing the sword. The blade's point in leather scabbards is usually protected by a metal **tip** , or [chape](/wiki/Chape "Chape"), which on both leather and metal scabbards is often given further protection from wear by an extension called a **drag** , or **shoe**.[84]
  * **Sword belt** : A sword belt is a [belt](/wiki/Belt_\(clothing\) "Belt \(clothing\)") with an attachment for the sword's scabbard, used to carry it when not in use. It is usually fixed to the scabbard of the sword, providing a fast means of drawing the sword in battle. Examples of sword belts include the [Balteus](/wiki/Balteus_\(sword_belt\) "Balteus \(sword belt\)") used by the [Roman legionary](/wiki/Roman_legionary "Roman legionary").[85]

## Typology[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Sword&action=edit&section=26 "Edit
section: Typology")]

Main articles: [Types of swords](/wiki/Types_of_swords "Types of swords") and
[Classification of swords](/wiki/Classification_of_swords "Classification of
swords")

Further information: [Sword replica](/wiki/Sword_replica "Sword replica")

Sword typology is based on morphological criteria on one hand (blade shape
(cross-section, taper, and length), shape and size of the hilt and pommel) and
age and place of origin on the other ([Bronze Age](/wiki/Bronze_Age_sword
"Bronze Age sword"), [Iron Age](/wiki/Iron_Age_sword "Iron Age sword"),
European (medieval, early modern, modern), Asian).

The relatively comprehensive [Oakeshott typology](/wiki/Oakeshott_typology
"Oakeshott typology") was created by historian and illustrator [Ewart
Oakeshott](/wiki/Ewart_Oakeshott "Ewart Oakeshott") as a way to define and
catalogue European swords of the medieval period based on physical form,
including blade shape and hilt configuration. The typology also focuses on the
smaller, and in some cases contemporary, single-handed swords such as the
[arming sword](/wiki/Arming_sword "Arming sword").[64]

### Single and double-
edged[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Sword&action=edit&section=27 "Edit section:
Single and double-edged")]

As noted above, the terms [longsword](/wiki/Longsword "Longsword"), [broad
sword](/wiki/Broad_sword "Broad sword"), [great sword](/wiki/Great_sword
"Great sword"), and [Gaelic claymore](/wiki/Claymore "Claymore") are used
relative to the era under consideration, and each term designates a particular
type of sword.

#### Jian[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Sword&action=edit&section=28 "Edit
section: Jian")]

In most Asian countries, a sword ([jian](/wiki/Jian "Jian") 劍, geom (검),
ken/tsurugi (剣), pedang) is a double-edged straight-bladed weapon, while a
knife or saber ([dāo](/wiki/D%C4%81o "Dāo") 刀, do (도),
to/[katana](/wiki/Katana "Katana") (刀), pisau, golok) refers to a single-edged
object.

#### Kirpan[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Sword&action=edit&section=29 "Edit
section: Kirpan")]

In Sikh history, the sword is held in very high esteem. A single-edged sword
is called a kirpan, and its double-edged counterpart a khanda or tega.[86]

#### Churika[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Sword&action=edit&section=30 "Edit
section: Churika")]

The [South Indian](/wiki/South_Indian "South Indian")
_[churika](/w/index.php?title=Churika&action=edit&redlink=1 "Churika \(page
does not exist\)")_ is a handheld double-edged sword traditionally used in the
[Malabar region](/wiki/Malabar_region "Malabar region") of
[Kerala](/wiki/Kerala "Kerala"). It is also worshipped as the weapon of
[Vettakkorumakan](/wiki/Vettakkorumakan "Vettakkorumakan"), the hunter god in
Hinduism.

#### Backsword and
falchion[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Sword&action=edit&section=31 "Edit section:
Backsword and falchion")]

European terminology does give generic names for single-edged and double-edged
blades but refers to specific types with the term 'sword' covering them all.
For example, the [backsword](/wiki/Backsword "Backsword") may be so called
because it is single-edged but the [falchion](/wiki/Falchion "Falchion") which
is also single-edged is given its own specific name.[87]

#### Two-handed[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Sword&action=edit&section=33 "Edit
section: Two-handed")]

See also: [Two-handed sword](/wiki/Two-handed_sword "Two-handed sword")

Two-handed sword may be used to refer to any sword that usually requires two
hands to wield. However, in its proper sense it should be used only to refer
to the very large swords of the 16th century.[81]

Throughout history two-handed swords have generally been less common than
their one-handed counterparts, one exception being their common use in Japan.

#### Hand and a half
sword[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Sword&action=edit&section=34 "Edit section:
Hand and a half sword")]

A Hand and a half sword, colloquially known as a "[bastard
sword](/wiki/Bastard_sword "Bastard sword")", was a sword with an extended
grip and sometimes pommel so that it could be used with either one or two
hands. Although these swords may not provide a full two-hand grip, they
allowed its wielders to hold a [shield](/wiki/Shield "Shield") or parrying
dagger in their off hand, or to use it as a two-handed sword for a more
powerful blow.[44] These should not be confused with a
[longsword](/wiki/Longsword "Longsword"), [two-handed sword](/wiki/Two-
handed_sword "Two-handed sword"), or [Zweihänder](/wiki/Zweih%C3%A4nder
"Zweihänder"), which were always intended to be used with two hands.

## Fictional types[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Sword&action=edit&section=35
"Edit section: Fictional types")]

In [fantasy](/wiki/Fantasy "Fantasy"), [magic swords](/wiki/Magic_sword "Magic
sword") often appear, based on their use in myth and legend. The [science
fiction](/wiki/Science_fiction "Science fiction") counterpart to these is
known as an energy sword (sometimes also referred to as a "beam sword" or
"laser sword"), a sword whose blade consists of, or is augmented by,
concentrated energy. A well known example of this type of sword is the
[lightsaber](/wiki/Lightsaber "Lightsaber"), primarily shown in the _[Star
Wars](/wiki/Star_Wars "Star Wars")_ franchise.

qa.question: what is the meaning of sword in english
qa.answer: ['a bladed weapon intended for slashing or thrusting that is longer than a knife or dagger']
